page.title:
Mobile Device Equipment Security Mobile device equipment presents a unique set of security concerns due to their portability. These devices include, but are not limited to:
Mobile Device Equipment
Security
Mobile device equipment presents a unique set
of security concerns due to their portability.
These devices include, but are not limited to:
page.enlisting:
– Laptops – Portable computers – Personal Digital Assistants (PDA) – Compact Discs (CD) – Digital Video Devices (DVD) – Flash drives

– Portable computers – P o r t a b l e

page.title:
Mobile Device Equipment Security
Mobile Device Equipment
Security
page.normal_text:
Contractors must consider the physical security of these devices and the protection of the confidential and/or sensitive information that is often stored on them.
Contractors must consider the physical
security of these devices and the
protection of the confidential and/or
sensitive information that is often stored
on them.

page.title:
Mobile Device Equipment Guidelines
Mobile Device Equipment
Guidelines
page.normal_text:
The following guidelines are intended to help improve the protection of mobile device equipment.
The following guidelines are intended to
help improve the protection of mobile
device equipment.

page.title:
Physical Security of Mobile Devices Do’s and Don’ts
Physical Security of Mobile
Devices
Do’s and Don’ts
page.enlisting:
• Don’t store your password with your mobile device. • Don’t leave your mobile device in your car. – Don’t leave your mobile device on the seat or even locked in • Don’t store your mobile in checked luggage. – Never store your mobile device in checked luggage. Always – You should secure your mobile device with a strong password, but don’t keep the password in the carrying case or on a piece of paper attached to the equipment. • Don’t carry mobile devices in easily identifiable carrying cases. – Particularly when traveling through airports, mobile devices should be kept in briefcases, backpacks, or other carrying cases that are not obvious. • Don’t store your password with your mobile device.
• Don’t store your password with your mobile device. • D o n ’ t

page.title:
Physical Security of Mobile Devices Do’s and Don’ts (continued)
Physical Security of Mobile
Devices
Do’s and Don’ts (continued)
page.enlisting:
• Do secure your mobile device when unattended. – Attach the mobile device with a security cable to something • Do keep track of your mobile device when you go through – Hold onto your mobile device until the person in front of you • Do record identifying information and mark your equipment. • Do backup your files. – Record the make, model, and serial number of the equipment and keep it in a separate location. Consider having the outside of the equipment case labeled with your agency’s contact information. – Make a backup of your files before every trip. In the event that your mobile device is lost or stolen, you will still have a copy of your data. • Do secure your mobile device when unattended.

page.title:
Data Security on Mobile Devices
Data Security on Mobile Devices
page.enlisting:
• If your mobile device contains confidential and/or sensitive • Insure that all files that reside on your mobile device are: – Regularly backed up to a secure server or other media (e.g. CD or flash drive) – Stored in a secure location – Encrypted • Any mobile device that is lost, stolen, or damaged must • If your mobile device contains confidential and/or sensitive

page.title:
About Encryption
About Encryption
page.enlisting:
What is encryption? • Encryption is the coding of data so that it cannot be read by anyone who does not know the password that decodes it. • Encryption garbles your data by using irreversible mathematical functions in order to make it nearly impossible to retrieve.
What is encryption?
